values: My girlfriend (the main person I'm seeing--I don't know what else to call her, and the other people I'm seeing don't really count right now) suddenly started expressing Emotion and I suddenly have no idea what to do. Things were great--we had a very physical, very alcoholic relationship that was working and now suddenly I'm sieged by... feelings, wishes that I could make her feel whole and right again, all kinds of terrible things I never wanted to feel. I don't get it at all. There are days when I feel like the luckiest guy on earth. There are other days when I want someone to shoot me in the face. Also, LASIK rocks. Go and get it. =)

I don't know why, but I want to let everyone who reads this know that I miss them. (Unless I've never met you. I guess I can't miss you if we've never met.) Come to think of it, I do know why. I'm getting closer to someone I actually think about and miss every day. Almost every hour of every day, at least when I'm awake. As a result, I'm much more social and kindly disposed. Plus it's spring, so I'm wallowing in bunny sex endorphins. As a weird corollary to this, I've lost my glasses. Everything looks airbrushed and beautiful. Without the acute feeling of points and hard edges intruding on my vision, my analytical glare just melts away. Cute girls smile at me when I'm not glaring at them. :P (I'm reluctant to get replacements, as a result. I'm actually happier and a lot easier to get along with when things look airbrushed and soft. This reinforces my idea that my vision problems are psychosomatic. I know I can improve my vision with NLP-style reframing because I've been trying it and succeeding for short periods of time. I'm at a loss as to how the secondary benefits of my myopia should be dealt with, though.)

Finding weekend work is a lot more difficult than I imagined. I wish I could get another mortgage job, because they pay well and I have experience, but nobody seems to hire for weekends or off-hours. 

I had a good weekend. On Friday I went with a bunch of people to a 1-hour open bar and then we wandered around SoHo looking for interesting places. On Saturday I went to Contempt and met a really attractive, interesting girl. Hopefully I'll be seeing a lot of her.

I also spoke to one of the people responsible for putting the event together, which is always rewarding. I'd like to be behind the scenes at subculture events myself, so learning more about them is useful and interesting. I really wish NYC had more, even for subcultures I'm not personally interested in. My suspicion is that there's more demand than there is supply, and that maybe a bit of inventiveness could easily turn small crowds into big ones and amplify the energy of the event at the same time.

It's been a long time since I stayed up all night studying for a test. My Greek professor has been telling us all year not to bother with the Greek into English translation exercises in the textbook, and I think I've been having a harder time because of it. Now I'm doing them, and the whole language seems much more clear.

In other news, I need to refresh my C++ knowledge and I want to do it by writing a program to generate random well-formed sentences in Greek. The problem is, I can't figure out how to keep the program simple (as in, within my ability) and use Unicode to display the Greek alphabet. Other people have tried the same thing and some of them must have succeeded, but none of the help pages I've looked at have been helpful.

I haven't updated in ages. I forgot about livejournal almost entirely. I've been really unsocial lately, so I decided to go out to a club for some loud industrial music on Saturday. I felt like I was being brought back to life, so I might need to do that more often. School is going really well. I'm finally starting to pick up Ancient Greek at a reasonable pace, after dragging through my first semester because I couldn't remember things. I switched my major to computer science for a few reasons, mostly because experience with computational modeling will serve my interests better than anything else. I plan to take a hard look at bioinformatics when I'm closer to having a degree. It's really sad that Robert Anton Wilson died. Like others, I sent the poor guy money when I found out he was struggling to pay rent, which ultimately made his death seem more personal somehow. I started reading Cosmic Trigger when I heard, so that I was reading it on the subway during Improv Everywhere's annual no pants subway ride. (That's me reading it in the first picture on the page, on the right) There's a coincidence buried in there somewhere.

<lj-cut text="Really unusual dream">
My divorced parents took me through the route we used to take to the park when I was 3-4.  The actual terrain was completely bizarre.  We walked next to a swamp with a tree whose roots were enormous and above-ground, stretching completely across the swamp as a natural bridge.  The roots were 6-7 feet in diameter.  As I walked on them, reaching different parts seemed to "trigger" events.  Suddenly bubbles would appear next to me and a fish would poke out of the water and say something odd before diving back under.  Once or twice, little pictures of Bugs Bunny suddenly appeared in the sky in front of me and sort of jingled.  We got to some kind of cabin where the same thing kept happening.  I'd walk next to a basket and after a pause, a bunch of apples would pour out.  I'd walk next to a piano and a little tune would play.  I walked next to a little room that branched from the main one and a door pushed me further in, then a bunch of things happened at once.  Bugs Bunny appeared again with that same jingling sound, another piano started to play, things dumped from barrels and baskets, papers in folders swayed back and forth, and I think the window opened and closed a few times.  It was all really strange.  It wasn't like there was a poltergeist, it was like a bunch of invisible children were just showing me what the things could do.  Except for Bugs Bunny - I don't know what was up with that.  Or the fish.  If you've ever played one of those "shooting games" like they have at the Mall of America, where you "shoot" targets and then something happens (shoot the target next to the beaver and the beaver moves, shoot the target next to the clock and a bird pops out, shoot the guy at the piano and he starts to play it, etc) the whole feeling was a lot like that.  Everything had a mechanical pause before kicking into action.</lj-cut>

Go see A Scanner Darkly! It's maybe the most thought-provoking movie I've ever seen. It reminded me a little of 1984. It's based on the Philip K. Dick novel of the same name. There's something uncanny about the whole story, it's sort of chilling and electrifying at the same time. Also incredibly funny, in a way. My favorite part (taken from the book, but faithfully translated in the film): "--this guy," Luckman was saying, manicuring a box full of grass, hunched over it as Arctor sat across from him, more or less watching, "appeared on TV claiming to be a world-famous impostor. He had posed at one time or another, he told the interviewer, as a great surgeon at Johns Hopkins Medical College, a theoretical submolecular high-velocity particle-research physicist on a federal grant at Harvard, as a Finnish novelist who'd won the Nobel Prize in literature, as a deposed president of Argentina married to--" "And he got away with all that?" Arctor asked. "He never got caught?" "The guy never posed as any of those. He never posed as anything but a world-famous impostor. That came out later in the L.A. Times--they checked up. The guy pushed a broom at Disneyland, or had until he read this autobiography about this world-famous impostor--there really was one--and he said, 'Hell, I can pose as all those exotic dudes and get away with it like he did,' and then he decided, 'Hell, why do that; I'll just pose as another impostor.' He made a lot of bread that way, the Times said. Almost as much as the real world-famous impostor. And he said it was a lot easier." (I didn't think that story got quite enough emphasis in the film. It leads into sort of a central concept. I think he says "money" instead of "bread" in the film.)
7/1/06 - Mission objective "survive 1 year in New York City" has been completed.  Formulation of successive objectives is underway.

Yarr, so I'm goin' back to college. Hunter College accepted me (so says the admissions hotline - they haven't sent anything yet) I'm going for anthropology, but I'll really be studying cybernetics, which is completely fascinating. I want to figure out what cultures and subcultures and little backwaters of civilization are actually doing in the bigger picture. Plus I want to figure out what it means for cultures to change. This'll naturally branch out in to studying cults, religions, sex, drugs, pirate enclaves, The Free State of Fiume, and other strange wonders. And burgeoning tribal structures in the modern US. I'll promote the idea that tribes are a Good Thing(tm) (unless I honestly can't find any support) and figure out how they work best. I've never been to a Real college before - the type that awards degrees and such. Their anthro department has a genetics lab! Gods! I can take genetics courses! I'm so happy I could choke!

NIN was a decent show.  Reznor's energy seems forced - I'm not sure he hates himself anymore.

I walked ~11 miles yesterday due to a major issue with Google Maps.  Jones Beach Theatre is *not* at 1542 Wantagh Ave in Wantagh, NY.  It's actually in JONES BEACH (hence the name) roughly 8 miles south.  I power-walked it in less than 2 hours (my legs are still sore) and missed Peaches and the beginning of Bauhaus.

Also, I've realized that a *good concert* for any high-energy group requires a mosh pit.  I really need to be brutally assaulted by a sweating mob of thrashing people who're far more into the music than I am to be properly immersed in the show.

Maybe I'd do better in college if lectures had a mosh pit.  Maybe quantum mechanics needs a thrash metal treatment.

<lj-cut text="Dietary note to self">
Diet prior to last excursion into MN:
Included: fresh/dried fruits & vegetables, unprocessed meats, spices, honey, tree nuts, tea, milk, eggs, cheese
Excluded: grains, potatoes, refined sugars, chemicals, additives, flavor enhancers, preservatives, etc.
Sleep pattern: came naturally, lasted 6 hours, woke up feeling refreshed and awake

During/after last excursion into MN:
Included: everything.  examples include Monster energy drinks, french fries, deep fried cheese curds (a strictly Midwestern phenomenon?), hot dogs (ech, wonderful definitely-not-meat aftertaste), the best damned pie on Earth (AFAIK), canned fruit, marshmallows, others
Sleep pattern: followed exhaustion, involved waking every few hours, ended after 12 hours feeling "too tired to continue sleeping", woke up feeling groggy and inertly homicidal
</lj-cut>
Conclusion: the primitive diet Works and Is good

WtT was excellent.  Lots to think on & examine.  I wish mushrooms got big enough to live in.

4QF has a labyrinth!  Doublepluscool.

I chipped a tooth battling a ferocious monster - I managed to escape with only a vicious ring of purple sucking-marks, but I took a nasty blow to the head and woke up with a terrible headache.  Beauty can be dangerous.

Oof. This was an insane week. Saw tons of MN friends and missed out on a lot more. Note to self: next time just pre-organize group events and invite everyone to everything. Publish the invitation list and update it in real-time so if Person X wants to avoid Person Y, they can do that. (this post inspired by "hey, Nick didn't even call me" second-hand messages and "wtf? you said we were gonna do something" notes. Deserved, but unpleasant.)
I scavenged my apartment for coins to fund my camping trip this weekend.  It filled a lunchbox.  Thinking I had $60 or $70, I was pretty happy.  It came out to $232.43

To all of you sashimi-eaters out there:

I have a friend who has agreed that he needs to try raw fish.  To overcome his sense of revulsion, he has decided to accompany the experience with quantities of sake.  To this end, I'm devising a Sushi Drinking Game using elements found in a sushi-serving environment.  Suggestions, anyone?

According to this YouTube now allows direct video upload from cell phones. This exactly solves a problem. Police who break down raves and other gatherings, sometimes quite brutally, at times confiscate video equipment. Victims of abuses are thus unable to present recorded evidence of wrongdoing. This YouTube upload thing can solve that by allowing people to upload immediately. Other applications are obvious. Imagine an invasion/occupation where the residents had access to this technology.
I think I'm living someone's dream.  I have no job to get up for every morning, I'm supporting myself with savings, and I have no active obligations of any sort.  It's kind of wonderful.

Find your own pose!

I give this test points for uniqueness, unrelatedness of questions to the subject, and displaying a position I've fallen into before. *** Has anyone out there heard of Marko Rodin? Has anyone formed an opinion? Tell me, so I can twist your opinion into a pretzel that will accurately reflect my opinion.

My winter hibernation is over.  How is everyone?

I spent all day yesterday in Union Square, next to the farmer's market.  It was nearly 80 degrees!  I've never been so happy to get a sunburn.

I'm really bored these days, as I'm jobless and loath to jump back into another 9-5 sentence.  In the meantime, I'm scouring craigslist for something I can do at night.  Anyone want to help?

If anyone out there is on Rupert Murdoch's networking toy, check out http://myspace.com/mnemne

Job-less, car-less, phone-less.  Meh.

On the upside, I was free to see The Sisters of Mercy on Wednesday.  It was a small crowd and a bunch of middle-aged thrasher types actually started moshing.  The guitarists explained after the show that they were picked up for the tour more or less at random.  A little girl gave me a pixy stix and some strangers brought me to Delaware and we talked until the sun came up.

Life is good.  I need a job.

personality tests by similarminds.com Still resolving this one. I got a *1* for sympathy? A 2 for altruism? On the other end of the scale, a 91 on confidence, a 92 on adventurousness, a 94 on liberalism, and a 95 on intellect. Hm.

This weekend will be locked in memory for awhile.  I finally took the opportunity to head to the Metropolitan Museum of Art and track down the original stone relief sculpture that inspired the miniature reproduction I have in my apartment.  I completely filled my camera's memory with pictures.  Not noticeable on my reproduction are the pomegranates lining the figure's robe.  Pomegranates!  My favorite food, possibly.  After that and other adventures, I had more fun in Astoria.  (It's a secret, but I did something interesting.)

In other news, I finally ordered more ram.  I'll have 1.5gb after I receive it.  Hopefully this will allow me to run Civ IV properly.

Civ IV is interesting.  The prerequisite technology for the Mount Rushmore wonder is Fascism.  I boggled at this until I really thought about it.  Video games are getting political.  I like that.  Maybe.

I'm feeling vaguely sinister, for some reason.  Not so much in the evil/wicked/creepy way, more in the sense that the left/sinistral side is "connected" to the "right brain" and is so associated with creativity.  I'm inclined to just shrug and step out of the way of my creative side and let it do as it will.  I think that's half of abandoning the sticky side of things - just letting things happen.

Alright, question for everyone who reads this - in the last line of that poem that's synonymous with the statue of liberty, "I lift my lamp beside the golden door" - is that New York City?  Is it Ellis Island?  Is it America?  In my youth I thought it was a reference to heaven, but that seems totally backward to me now.

Not a bad day. With help, I discovered that my car is not so badly damaged as I'd been led to believe. I consider it likely that my car was intentionally damaged by the mechanic who looked at it and adequate forms of retribution are being taken into consideration. (I don't know for a fact that the damage was intentional, but the service station was screwing with me and it seems incredibly unlikely that my engine would quietly break apart in the middle of traffic the way it "apparently" did.) Also caught a play, which was nice. It killed me, because I'm prone to that kind of thing in the right environment. So in other words, my birthday wasn't a total debacle. Which is good, because November 19th is generally the one day in a given year when my luck really goes to hell. Not that it's really that bad - there's just usually one thing that seems to unbalance things in the direction of being unfortunate. I've also been in the newspaper for having a birthday party at a nature center, and that was pretty cool. (I must have been 6 or 7) Also picked up my day with a phone conversation - that was quite nice. So all in all, all I was missing was sushi. Just sushi. And I can remedy that. But I'd rather go to sleep.

In David Lynch's "Mulholland Drive" The Cowboy says at one point "if you do good, you'll see me one more time.  if you do bad, you'll see me two more times."
The actual character he's speaking to, I'm fairly certain, doesn't see him again in the movie.  The viewer, however, will see him at least once.  Possibly twice, but if and only if the viewer is paying attention to what's going on in the background during a party scene.  Which, I think, is part of what the whole movie is trying to combat on some level.  The guy behind the dumpster in the beginning is, I think, a warning on that level.
Urg, I feel like death.  I think I need a long nap.  And then I get to spend my birthday trying to retrieve my car.  Not the start I was looking for to my new year.

Highlight of my day: I'm staring at a cute 1-year-old in a stroller who's staring off in space and kicking her feet around; her name was Cimmaron though I might have gotten the spelling wrong. Me: I miss that age Kerron: What do you remember about that age? Me: I don't remember anything about that age. I just know it was good. This made the woman on my right start to laugh, and then a second later she started laughing even harder, before the first round stopped. Then she just continued laughing, and it was like she wasn't making sense of it but she could feel it and it kept getting deeper. It was kind of neat ;) In other news, I'm tripping out my coworkers. They keep asking me how I'm doing and it throws them off when I actually tell them and then ask how they are. It makes me stand out, but I really don't want to settle into that routine of habitually answering 'questions' like that without taking the time to consider what they mean. I'd sooner grunt like a pig than answer without meaning it. I always examine the content of communication. I wonder, how much is this like 'reading' the entrails of an animal? It's said by many that content accounts for practically nothing, it's like the error-checking digit in a number.
Hm.  My $825 car is now $1400 worth of dead.  I guess I need a new one.  Hm.

Great weekend, up until my car died on the Throgs Neck Bridge (thank you, my rescuers) and left me without a vehicle for getting to work.  Will be trying some combination of the LIRR, the Long Island bus system, and/or taxis to get in at a reasonable hour.

(In other news, my mother's birthday gift to me is an Ikea gift certificate that's still in the mail somewhere.  Will have a more reasonable furniture situation shortly.)

Socratic
You scored a 20 from -60 to 60.
You have a classic value system, a combination of reason, logic but a humility to the state or other institution. Socratics are almost mystics in that they believe there is something wholeheartedly more important going on behind the scenes of this world, almost a 'spirit' world where the mind lies. Their philosophy is driven by idealising this other world. Obviously, Socrates was a socratic.



My test tracked 1 variable How you compared to other people your age and gender:
You scored higher than 96% on Virtue Points
Link: The Philosophy Test written by austinwiltshire on Ok Cupid, home of the 32-Type Dating Test
 I edited this for typos. Bwahaha. (typos in quiz results really annoy me)

Yay, banking rocks.  I spent all day in training, which was actually fascinating.  Then my manager let everyone leave at 3pm.  And we have Friday off.  So my weekend started almost 3 hours ago.  And I finally got Civ IV on the way home.  *grins*

Strange dream, as I was sleeping from around 8pm to 2am:

A historical report was detailing how throughout history, large populations have "spontaneously" taken to grabbing big, long sticks and whacking at each other until only small numbers remained.  I "watched" this somehow, and a sort of moving force rushed through the armed populace, and there were always little knots of people beating down on everyone else.  This was relayed to me while I was in a business office on the moon, and another history report detailed how we were still living in the wake of the huge lunar cities being built.  The cities had been built not because Earth was uninhabitable or anything like that, but because people thought it was cool.
This just warms my heart... White House keeps dossiers on more than 10,000 'political enemies' I wish I had a way of verifying this. I probably do, somehow or another.

I wish I was doing laundry right now. But that would involve not being in my nice, warm apartment and it would involve being at the laundromat down the street. Thus, I will wear my one (1) remaining clean work-appropriate shirt tomorrow and then decide after work if I should buy more clothes or wash what I have. (I think I'm actually willing to pay to have my laundry done for me - must research this possibility) In other news, I'm going to be in Hawaii for the solstice. Then I come back the day before Xmas and stay for the week in Minnesota. Hopefully will have a treasured presence with me, but I think she needs convincing. ;)

Philly trip was awesome.  Lots of fun with authority at Target stores - I was permitted to be in back rooms and such on account of my traveling companion, who was doing work for them.  Managers wouldn't look at me or anything, though - they acknowledged us on their radios as "gentlemen" but they didn't speak to me, look at me, attempt to shake my hand, or anything.  I think they were intimidated!  That's so odd, but I think I'm right.  I seem so un-intimidating to myself, and it's not like I'm big or anything - I don't get it.  But when I took the initiative and put out my hand for the management types, they got nervous almost with a "deer in headlights" kind of look and shook my hand while trying to avoid eye contact.  Gods, I don't understand it.

My new favorite word: inexorable
Webster's definition: not to be persuaded or moved by entreaty : RELENTLESS

(and I've been insomnia-bombed.  it's 2am and I'm dead awake.  seasonal shift, I think)
Yeehaw!  A friend from Minnesota is in NY doing some electrical work and offered me $100 to help him out in Philly tomorrow.  I'm going!
Wow, I've been misspelling the word "sensitive" as "sensetive" for probably my whole life.  *boggles*

Grr. After making a few dozen phone calls to every video game retailer in Queens and Manhattan (I got the yellow pages directory info and just went down the list) I finally found a Gamestop in Manhattan that said they had it. "Do you have Civilization IV?" "let me check... yeah" "Do you have a lot of them?" "yeah" --- So I threw on some chainmail (I've got it for Halloween, thanks Karen, I decided that I might as well get a workout as I wander Manhattan) and stopped in for some home-made rice pudding (and, while I waited, a double-shot of 1800 - Lauren, someday I will introduce you to this!) next to the subway station. So after the crawl to 34th streeth, I got out and found the place - it's at 33rd & Broadway in case someone wants to lob an egg or two for me. "Do you have Civilization IV?" "No, we sold out in like five minutes" "I called an hour ago and they told me you had lots!" At this point I think the guy realized he was the one who spoke to me over the phone. "Oh. Uh. My supervisor just said we sold out." So I tracked down Firaxis (they apparently *had* an office in Manhattan) which was supposedly at 1841 Broadway and it doesn't exist. So I muttered and crawled back onto the subway, slightly relieved at being able to sit down. Chain mail is heavy. Good workout, though. And I still want that game.

Mission thwarted. Civ4 was released to a limited list of retailers and is sold out of those outposts in my area. Researching. (Stopping at Queens Center Mall afforded me an opportunity to stop in at Godiva for a dark chocolixir. Breastfast of the gods, I swear.) Also glanced the guy who saluted and shalomed me the day before Yom Kippur. I feel bad about that, now. I assumed it was some jerkoff who wanted a dollar and was hoping I was Jewish and would respond favorably to such a greeting. I saluted him back and started walking into the store, but then he called out "no, wait! how are you?" and I said "I'm just fine" as I kept walking. He didn't follow me in, but the more I thought about it, the less likely it seemed that he wanted my dollar. Strangely, today, he came up to the front door - I thought he must be a neighbor. But he just looked in for a second and then went on his way. I kind of wanted to say hi. (I wish I could've recalled what shalom meant, I had no idea it's a standard greeting. What would've happened if I said it back? It seems so secret, Hebrew on the streets, idunno. I guess I just never heard it in real life, it's one of those languages I've only heard in movies. Welcome to New York.) I love New York. (I still find it weird when people make comments at work about October being a Jewish holiday as the reason for there being no work for us to do. Only there isn't any work for us to do and we're getting emails about law offices being closed and borrowers being on vacation because they're Jewish. In Minnesota, drawing a correlation like that would've been as bad as using the 'n' word in regular conversation. Nobody here seems to find it strange.)
Wow, Civ4 is apparently out now.  I'm heading out in a second to pick up a copy-

Sigh.  The key to my apartment building broke off inside the lock.
(It had help, though I didn't catch his name.  Friendly guy, one of my downstairs neighbors.)
So now the door is out of commission and the super is missing.
Hm.

In other news, I'd rather be late to work than have unwashed hair.
(I found out this morning with certainty, and remarkably I was on time despite that)
When camping, I don't care.  It's a different thing.
Added a couple of people as lj friends - if you're reading this and you're one of them, I send my greetings.

I was *this* close to hunting someone down today.  I went to refill my cup with water and lost myself for a moment in this wonderful light, spicy fragrance that drifted off in the direction of the sales department.  I knew who it was immediately (I've noticed her before; she's middle-aged and actually going through a divorce, but she's not unattractive and she's younger than she looks) and had a long moment before I decided not to chase her.  The problem was knowing who it was, I hate to feign ignorance.  The smell caught me so much because of other things going through me - the scent was so mysterious and playful, it came from somewhere else.

From http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ambrosia

One of the impieties of Tantalus, according to Pindar, was that he offered to his guests the ambrosia of the Deathless Ones, a theft akin to that of Prometheus, Karl Kerenyi noted (in Heroes of the Greeks). Circe mentioned to Odysseus that a flock of doves brought the ambrosia to Olympus.

Derivatively, the word Ambrosia (neuter plural) was given to certain festivals in honour of Dionysus, probably because of the predominance of feasting in connection with them.

"Ambrosia" is related to the Hindu amrita, a drink which conferred immortality on the gods.

Many modern scholars like Danny Staples relate ambrosia to the hallucinogenic mushroom Amanita muscaria.

Interesting times.  My appetite is gone - this happens every year.  My lunch costs $2 - just a cup with yogurt & fresh fruit & granola.  On the upside, I'm getting nourishment elsewhere.  Like skipping out between the hours for pulls of milk & honey. (I suspect "milk & honey" is considered a captured asset by some major religion.  these things should breathe freely)

In other news, my coffee cycle is -over-.  The unpleasant, allergic-feeling reaction just bounded ahead of the awake, chemically-assisted alertness reaction.
Back to black tea or nothing, for awhile.
(It turns out that I actually *like* Earl Grey if it's got lemon.  Bergamot goes badly with sugar.)
